frameDefinitions: In this frame an Action is evaluated with respect to how fairly, justly or equitably the Action affects the Affected_party.
This frame concerns an Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.
An Agent (the punisher or rewarder) performs a Response_action on an Evaluee for a Reason, the Evaluee's actions or beliefs.
An Entity persists in a stable situation called a State
Using Evidence, which may or may not be expressed, a Cognizer recognizes or proves that Concept1 is associated causally or collocationally with another concept, Concept2.
An Agent causes a Theme to move away from a location, the Source.
frameExamples: Smithers was being very <t>fair</t> about the distribution of supplies.
His <t>punishment</t> of the prisoners was too harsh.
I saw that several men in dark suits had <t>removed</t> all of the evidence from the scene.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Actor</fen> is the individual who performs the <fen>Action</fen> and can thus be characterized with repsect to how that <fen>Action</fen> affects the <fen>Affected_party</fen>.
The <fen>Action</fen> is judged based on how just and appopriate it is to the <fen>Affected_party</fen> in a particular situation.
The <fen>Grounds</fen> is the event or state that requires some decision or action in response to it for which the <fen>Actor</fen> is judged.
The <fen>Affected_party</fen>'s treatment is what determines the evaluation of the <fen>Actor</fen>'s <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged for its quality.
This role marks expressions that denote a scalar property of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> with respect to which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged.
<fen>Evaluee</fen> is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment has made and to whom reward/punishment is dealt. With verbs, the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is typically expressed as Object.
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <fen>Reason</fen> for the <fen>Agent</fen>'s judgment. It is usually a 'for'-PP, e.g.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person doing the rewarding or punishing.
The reward or punishment given to the <fen>Evaluee</fen> by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
Concrete or abstract entity
State of an Entity.
<fen>Concept1</fen> is the phenomenon which is believed to be related to <fen>Concept2</fen>.
The phenomenon which is believed to be linked to Concept1.
The sentient entity that recognizes the causal connection.
The phenomena which are believed to be related.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> make the connection.
The location where the Cognizer makes the connection.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person (or other force) that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to move.
Theme is the object that changes location.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the initial location of the <fen>Theme</fen>, before it changes location.
The non-Agentive cause of the removing event.
The time at which the removal takes place.
The location where the removal takes place.
listRoleExamples: The Beaujolais Nouveau is dazzling <fex>in freshness</fex>.
The boss rewarded <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
<fex>Jake's</fex> rewards to his best workers were very generous.
If a person be guilty of impiety let him be punished <fex>with death</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> removed the dishes from the table.
The waiter removed <fex>the dishes</fex> from the table.
The waiter removed the dishes <fex>from the table</fex>.
<fex>The raging fire</fex> quickly emptied the square of all people.
<fex>That year</fex> they drained the swamp-water out of Higgs' bottomland.
You just take the dishes and rinse them <fex>in the kitchen</fex>, okay?

passageCandidateSpans.text: Rule 60 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure

sourceCandidateSpans.text: §200(4) of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act
Timing and Effect of the Motion
Other Methods of Relief From Judgment
Correction of Clerical Mistakes in Orders and Decrees
Perlman v. 322 West Seventy-Second Street Co., Inc.
Reed v. South Atlantic Steamship Co.
